prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 2028, band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: detect CO(2-1) line to measure gas mass, and (possibly) HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) transitions to study the gas chemistry

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity:
1) In our "baseline model", we estimate the expected CO luminosity L'(CO) following the Daddi et al. (2010) relation between LIR(8-1000 micron) and L'CO for SF galaxies. As mentioned in the Scientific Justification, this choice is justified by the fact that our targets lie on average on the main sequence of SF galaxies at z~1.5. LIR is estimated from a direct fit to the Herschel photometry, and decomposing the SF and AGN component (logLIR=12.4 Lsun) and the corresponding L'CO(2-1) is logL'CO=10.5.
2) The CO line intensity S(CO) is calculated from L'(CO) according to Solomon & Vanden Bout (2005) and is 0.93 Jy km/s, with a peak flux of 2.3 mJy, assuming an expected FWHM of 400 km/s.
3) A sensitivity of 0.45 mJy over a 50 km/s channel will assure a S/N=5 detection of the line (in case of lower FWHM of the line core the detection will be even more significant).
4) We stress that even in the most conservative assumption (e.g. a peak flux of 1.0 mJy using the Genzel et al. 2010 relation for SMG between the LFIR(50-300 micron)=LIR/1.3 and L'CO) the same integration time (25 min) will return a ~0.32 mJy rms over a channel of 100 km/s, assuring a S/N=3 detection. See also Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.
Imaging requirements: We ask for a 1" resolution: this will enable to assess the presence of substructure in the CO on the galaxy scale, without over-resolving any significant flux.
Correlator setup: We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwith of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~3 km/s. Baseband 1 will cover the CO(2-1) line (width of ~100 MHz). Baseband 2 and 3 will be observing the continuum, and Baseband 4 will be placed in the range expected for the HCN(3-2) and HCO+(3-2) transitions. We will also apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 4, in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s. In the line analyses, the data will be further binned in channels of 50 km/s up to 100 km/s, which are the value used to compute the sensitivity and observing time.
Standard calibrations are requested.
The total time on-source for this science goal is 25 minutes and the total time including calibrations and overhead is 0.9 hrs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 5321, band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
detect CO(2-1) line to measure gas mass, and (possibly) HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) transitions to study the gas chemistry.
This is our faintest target.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(SAME as SG 1, changes are only in the numbers of expected fluxes and S/N of the detection). See also Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.
Requested sensitivity:
1) In our "baseline model", we estimate the expected CO luminosity L'(CO) following the Daddi et al. (2010) relation between LIR(8-1000 micron) and L'CO for SF galaxies. As mentioned in the Scientific Justification, this choice is justified by the fact that our targets lie on average on the main sequence of SF galaxies at z~1.5. LIR is estimated from a direct fit to the Herschel photometry, and decomposing the SF and AGN component (logLIR=12.2 Lsun) and the corresponding L'CO(2-1) is logL'CO=10.33.
2) The CO line intensity S(CO) is calculated from L'(CO) according to Solomon & Vanden Bout (2005) and is 0.71 Jy km/s, with a peak flux of 1.8 mJy, assuming an expected FWHM of 400 km/s.
3) A sensitivity of 0.35 mJy over a 50 km/s channel will assure a S/N=5 detection of the line (in case of lower FWHM of the line core the detection will be even more significant).
4) We stress that even in the most conservative assumption (e.g. a peak flux of 0.8 mJy using the Genzel et al. 2010 relation for SMG between the LFIR(50-300 micron)=LIR/1.3 and L'CO) the same integration time (40 min) will return a ~0.25 mJy rms over a channel of 100 km/s, assuring a S/N=3 detection. See also Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.
Imaging requirements: We ask for a 1" resolution: this will enable to assess the presence of substructure in the CO on the galaxy scale, without over-resolving any significant flux.
Correlator setup: We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwith of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~3 km/s. Baseband 1 will cover the CO(2-1) line (width of ~100 MHz). Baseband 2 and 3 will be observing the continuum, and Baseband 4 will be placed in the range expected for the HCN(3-2) and HCO+(3-2) transitions. We will also apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 4, in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s. In the line analyses, the data will be further binned in channels of 50 km/s up to 100 km/s, which are the value used to compute the sensitivity and observing time.
Standard calibrations are requested.
The total time on-source for this science goal is 40 minutes and the total time including calibrations and overhead is 1.3 hrs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 5395, band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
detect CO(2-1) line to measure gas mass, and (possibly) HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) transitions to study the gas chemistry.
This is our brightest target.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(SAME as SG 1, changes are only in the numbers of expected fluxes and S/N of the detection). See also Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.
Requested sensitivity:
1) In our "baseline model", we estimate the expected CO luminosity L'(CO) following the Daddi et al. (2010) relation between LIR(8-1000 micron) and L'CO for SF galaxies. As mentioned in the Scientific Justification, this choice is justified by the fact that our targets lie on average on the main sequence of SF galaxies at z~1.5. LIR is estimated from a direct fit to the Herschel photometry, and decomposing the SF and AGN component (logLIR=12.7 Lsun) and the corresponding L'CO(2-1) is logL'CO=10.77.
2) The CO line intensity S(CO) is calculated from L'(CO) according to Solomon & Vanden Bout (2005) and is 1.98 Jy km/s, with a peak flux of 4.90 mJy, assuming an expected FWHM of 400 km/s.
3) A sensitivity of 0.7 mJy over a 50 km/s channel will assure a S/N=7 detection of the line (in case of lower FWHM of the line core the detection will be even more significant).
4) We stress that even in the most conservative assumption (e.g. a peak flux of 2.1 mJy using the Genzel et al. 2010 relation for SMG between the LFIR(50-300 micron)=LIR/1.3 and L'CO) the same integration time (10 min) will return a ~0.5 mJy rms over a channel of 100 km/s, assuring a S/N=4 detection. See also Table 2 of the Scientific Justification.
Imaging requirements: We ask for a 1" resolution: this will enable to assess the presence of substructure in the CO on the galaxy scale, without over-resolving any significant flux.
Correlator setup: We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwith of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~3 km/s. Baseband 1 will cover the CO(2-1) line (width of ~100 MHz). Baseband 2 and 3 will be observing the continuum, and Baseband 4 will be placed in the range expected for the HCN(3-2) and HCO+(3-2) transitions. We will also apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 4, in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s. In the line analyses, the data will be further binned in channels of 50 km/s up to 100 km/s, which are the value used to compute the sensitivity and observing time.
Standard calibrations are requested.
The total time on-source for this science goal is 10 minutes and the total time including calibrations and overhead is 0.6 hrs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 5321, band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
detect CO(5-4) line (to measure excitation state), CO(5-4) wings (to quantify the outflow) and (possibly) HCN(6-5) and HCO+(6-5) transitions to study the gas chemistry and the dense regions.
This is our faintest target.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(see Figure 2f of the Scientific Justification, and Table 2)
Requested sensitivity:
We tuned the requested sensitivity in order to detect the broad wing in the CO(5-4) transition. We made the following assumptions :
1) We estimated the CO luminosity L'(CO) in the CO(5-4) transition scaling from the results by Aravena et al. (2008), e.g. assuming a ratio of 3.7 between the 5-4 transition and the 2-1 transition (predicted as for the first science goal). This is a conservative assumption, given that this object lies in the lower envelope of the CO SLEDs. This translates into a total flux of ~2.6 Jy km/s, with a peak flux of 6.5 mJy (S/N=32 over 100 km/s channels)
2) Among our targets, this source is the one most similar to IRASF08572 (e.g. highest AGN fraction, 80%, see Fig2b). We assume that 15% of the line flux is in a broad wing as observed in IRASF08572, e.g. ~0.4 Jy km/s. We model the wing with a gaussian peaked at 550 km/s (e.g. the shift observed in the [OIII] line) and with a FWHM=600 km/s. We estimate a continuum subtracted peak flux of ~0.65 mJy. This can be revealed at a S/N=3.2 with a sensitivity of 0.2 mJy in channels of 100 km/s.
3) With the same exposure time (42 min) we will reach an rms of 0.1 mJy in channels of 400 km/s which will enable us to detect an excess at S/N=3 below the wing peak, in the more conservative cases of: ** L'CO predicted from the Genzel et al. (2010) relation from SMG (expected peak flux in the wing of 0.3 mJy) ** wing flux assumed to be 7% of the core flux (e.g. the median value observed in the Cicone et al. 2013 sample; peak flux ~0.3 mJy).
4) We stress that given the lack of observations of this class of objects, and the evidences we have that AGN heating may be important (AGN fraction over the SED, ionised lines), the extrapolated fluxes in the CO(5-4) from the CO(2-1) transition based on COSBO11 should be actually considered as LOWER LIMITS: e.g. APM0827 shows prominent outflows in the ionized components and it has a considerably higher 5-4 to 2-1 ratio (~10; see also Weiss et al. 2007, CW13). The component of discovery space of this science goal may be therefore much larger than expected.
Imaging requirements: We ask for a 1" resolution: this will enable to assess the presence of substructure in the CO on the galaxy scale and resolve faint extended structures, without over-resolving any significant flux.
Correlator setup: We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwith of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~1 km/s. Baseband 1 will cover the CO(5-4) line. Baseband 2 will be observing the continuum, and Baseband 3 and 4 will be placed at frequencies such to observe the HCN(6-5) and HCO+(6-5) transition. We will apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 16 (10 km/s), in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s. In the analyses of the broad wings, the data will be binned in channels of 100 km/s to 400 km/s (depending on the flux of the source) which are the values used to compute the sensitivity and observing time.
The total time on-source for this science goal is 42 minutes and the total time including calibrations and overhead is 1.4 hrs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 2028, band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: detect CO(5-4) line (to measure excitation state), CO(5-4) wings (to quantify the outflow) and (possibly) HCN(7-6) and HCO+(7-6) transitions to study the gas chemistry and the dense regions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(SAME as SG 4, changes are only in the numbers of expected fluxes and S/N of the detection; see Table 2 of the Scientific Justification)
Requested sensitivity:
We tuned the requested sensitivity in order to detect the broad wing in the CO(5-4) transition. We made the following assumptions :
1) We estimated the CO luminosity L'(CO) in the CO(5-4) transition scaling from the results by Aravena et al. (2008), e.g. assuming a ratio of 3.7 between the 5-4 transition and the 2-1 transition (predicted as for the first science goal). This is a conservative assumption, given that this object lies in the lower envelope of the CO SLEDs. This translates into a total flux of ~3.4 Jy km/s, with a peak flux of 8.5 mJy (S/N=42 over 100 km/s channels)
2) We further assume that 15% of the line flux is in a broad wing (as for IRASF08572), which translates in a S(CO)~0.5 Jy km/s. We model the wing with a gaussian peaked at 350 km/s (e.g. the shift observed in the [OIII] line) and with a FWHM=600 km/s. We estimate a continuum subtracted peak flux of ~0.8 mJy. This can be revealed at a S/N=4.2 with a sensitivity of 0.2 mJy in channels of 100 km/s.
3) With the same exposure time (42 min) we will reach an rms of 0.1 mJy in channels of 400 km/s which will enable us to detect an excess at S/N>3 below the wing peak, in the more conservative cases of: ** L'CO predicted from the Genzel et al. (2010) relation from SMG (expected peak flux ~0.35 mJy) ** wing flux assumed to be 7% of the core flux (e.g. the median value observed in the Cicone et al. 2013 sample; peak flux ~0.4 mJy)
4) We stress that given the lack of observations of this class of objects, and the evidences we have that AGN heating may be important (AGN fraction over the SED, ionised lines), the extrapolated fluxes in the CO(5-4) from the CO(2-1) transition based on COSBO11 should be actually considered as LOWER LIMITS: e.g. APM0827 shows prominent outflows in the ionized components and it has a considerably higher 5-4 to 2-1 ratio (~10; see also Weiss et al. 2007, CW13). The component of discovery space of this science goal may be therefore much larger than expected.
Imaging requirements: We ask for a 1" resolution: this will enable to assess the presence of substructure in the CO on the galaxy scale and resolve faint extended structures, without over-resolving any significant flux.
Correlator setup: We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwith of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~1 km/s. Baseband 1 will cover the CO(5-4) line. Baseband 2 will be observing the continuum, and Baseband 3 and 4 will be placed at frequencies such to observe the HCN(7-6) and HCO+(7-6) transition. We will apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 16 (10 km/s), in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s. In the analyses of the broad wings, the data will be binned in channels of 100 km/s to 400 km/s (depending on the flux of the source) which are the values used to compute the sensitivity and observing time.
The total time on-source for this science goal is 42 minutes and the total time including calibrations and overhead is 1.4 hrs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XID 5395, band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: detect CO(5-4) line (to measure excitation state), CO(5-4) wings (to quantify the outflow) and (possibly) HCN(6-5) and HCO+(6-5) transitions to study the gas chemistry and the dense regions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(SAME as SG 4, changes are only in the numbers of expected fluxes and S/N of the detection; see Table 2 of the Scientific Justification). We note that, despite that XID5395 and XID5321 are at the same redshift, given the difference (a factor >3) on the expected peak flux, splitting the 2 sources in 2 separate science goals with different exposure times (42min and 13min) actually save ALMA time with respect to place both in the same science goal.
Requested sensitivity:
We tuned the requested sensitivity in order to detect the broad wing in the CO(5-4) transition. We made the following assumptions:
1) We estimated the CO luminosity L'(CO) in the CO(5-4) transition scaling from the results by Aravena et al. (2008), e.g. assuming a ratio of 3.7 between the 5-4 transition and the 2-1 transition (predicted as for the first science goal). This is a conservative assumption, given that this object lies in the lower envelope of the CO SLEDs. This translates into a total flux of ~7.2 Jy km/s, with a peak flux of 18 mJy (S/N=50 over 100 km/s channels).
2) we further assume that 15% of the line flux is in a broad wing (as observed in IRASF08572) with delta(V)=400 km/s (as observed in the [OII] line), e.g. ~1.1 Jy km/s. Assuming a gaussian profile and a broader FWHM (FWHM=600 km/s) we estimate a peak flux of ~1.8 mJy. This can be revealed at a S/N=6 with a sensitivity of 0.36 mJy in channels of 100 km/s.
3) With the same exposure time (13 min) we will reach an rms of 0.25 mJy in channels of 200 km/s which will enable us to detect an excess at S/N>3 below the wing peak, in the more conservative cases of: ** L'CO predicted from the Genzel et al. (2010) relation from SMG (expected peak flux of ~0.8 mJy) ** wing flux assumed to be 7% of the core flux (e.g. the median value observed in the Cicone et al. 2013 sample; peak flux ~1 mJy).
4) We stress that given the lack of observations of this class of objects, and the evidences we have that AGN heating may be important (AGN fraction over the SED, ionised lines), the extrapolated fluxes in the CO(5-4) from the CO(2-1) transition based on COSBO11 should be actually considered as LOWER LIMITS: e.g. APM0827 shows prominent outflows in the ionized components and it has a considerably higher 5-4 to 2-1 ratio (~10; see also Weiss et al. 2007, CW13). The component of discovery space of this science goal may be therefore much larger than predicted.
Imaging requirements: We ask for a 1" resolution: this will enable to assess the presence of substructure in the CO on the galaxy scale and resolve faint extended structures, without over-resolving any significant flux.
Correlator setup: We use 4 basebands in FDM with a bandwith of 1.875 GHz and a spectral resolution of ~1 km/s. Baseband 1 will cover the CO(5-4) line. Baseband 2 will be observing the continuum, and Baseband 3 and 4 will be placed at frequencies such to observe the HCN(6-5) and HCO+(6-5) transition. We will apply spectral averaging in the data transfer of a factor of 16 (10 km/s), in order to reduce the data rate to values <6 MB/s. In the analyses of the broad wings, the data will be binned in channels of 100 km/s to 400 km/s (depending on the flux of the source) which are the values used to compute the sensitivity and observing time.
The total time on-source for this science goal is 13 minutes and the total time including calibrations and overhead is 0.7 hrs.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to obtain CO(2-1) and CO(5-4) measurements in 3 luminous, X-ray selected obscured QSOs at z~1.5, expected to be in the blow-out/outflow phase predicted in several models of AGN-galaxy co-evolution. With a total of ~6.3 hours of observing time (including overheads), splitted in 6 science goals, and exploiting the unique information from the COSMOS survey, we will provide the first comprehensive study of the molecular gas content and fraction, excitation state, kinematics, and depletion timescales in three objects representative of a class of sources severely overlooked in previous molecular gas measurements at z=1-2. Moreover, all three targets already show convincing evidence of outflowing (ionised) material from X-Shooter or VIMOS spectra. They therefore represent the optimal targets to perform outflows studies in the molecular gas component, and we will do so by searching (and likely detecting) for broad wings in the CO(5-4) line.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
